multi_stage.description: _(Setting your location will help us list streams as safe. Your address will not be shared on the map.)
_(Tell us what you’ve done on your farm to protect natural resources)
_(Tell us what you’ve done to improve forest conservation)
_(Tell us what you’ve done to improve shoreline or streamside conservation)
_(Tell us what you’ve done to improve urban / surburban conservation)

fields.name: location-information
fields.content:
You may drag the map to set your location.
Or, you may enter your address:

body: A heavy use area is a small fenced in area with a footing such as gravel or hog fuel. Livestock are kept in this area during winter months to protect pasture soils and grasses.

body: A rain garden is an area that is dug out, lined with a special soil mix, and planted with the intent of infiltrating runoff from your house, driveway, or other hardened surfaces.

content.label: _(Installed a rain garden)
_(Installed a rain garden)

fields.name: urban_rain-gardens-datetime
fields.prompt: _(Approximately when did you last complete this action?)

content.label: _(Installed rain barrels or cisterns)
_(Installed rain barrels or cisterns)

fields.name: urban_rain-barrels-datetime
fields.prompt: _(Approximately when did you last complete this action?)

body: A rain bed combines a rain barrel system with a raised garden bed. A special gutter in the raised bed spreads water from the barrels over the garden for easy watering. Excess water from the barrels infiltrates through the bed and is dispersed over the surrounding yard where it is filtered and infiltrated.

content.label: _(Installed rain beds)
_(Installed rain beds)

body: Natural Yard Care can include: building healthy soil, practicing smart watering, using organic products, avoiding chemical use, mulching/composting and supporting pollinators.

content: Help us celebrate the power of community action! The purpose of this online tool is to collect information about the actions we are all taking to clean up our local streams and rivers.
Sharing what you have done on your property to keep our local waterways clean, improve wildlife habitat, or protect our natural resources for the future!

As we clean up our waterways, the Department of Ecology may use this information to justify removal of previously polluted streams from their "polluted waterbodies" list. This list lets the public know which waterways are safe for recreational contact and which ones still need our help.
